featureContentItems.dek: Are you fed up with cranky travelers, overpriced airport food, and the endless hunt for a power outlet? Check in to one of these swanky airport lounges, where amenities range from complimentary pajamas (for your slumber in a private nap room) to meals prepared by Michelin-starred chefs.

featureContentItems.hed: These Cliff Views Rival The Grand Canyon
featureContentItems.dek: Daredevils, this one's for you. The views from spots like the White Cliffs of Dover, Half Dome, and the Cliffs of Moher are as beautiful as they are vertigo-inducing.

featureContentItems.hed: 10 Unusual Foods We Dare You to Eat
featureContentItems.dek: Unless you have really adventurous taste buds, it might take a dare before you’re willing to sample any of these delicacies.

featureContentItems.hed: 10 Travel Gear Fails: The're So Bad, They're Genius
5 Easy Escapes from the World’s Top Business Centers
The One Dish to Eat in Venice

shortLinksItems.hed: 10 Unusual Foods We Dare You to Eat

shortLinksItems.dek: Are you fed up with cranky travelers, overpriced airport food, and the endless hunt for a power outlet? Check in to one of these swanky airport lounges, where amenities range from complimentary pajamas (for your slumber in a private nap room) to meals prepared by Michelin-starred chefs.

items.title: Delta Sky Club
items.caption: Part of a $1.2 billion expansion at JFK, Delta's 24,000-square-foot flagship Sky Club is also home to the airline's first Sky Deck, an outdoor terrace designed in conjunction with _Architectural Digest_.

items.title: Qatar Airways Premium Lounge
items.caption: Described as more of a boutique hotel or a private club than an airport lounge, visitors to Qatar Airways' Premium Lounge at Heathrow (the airline's first outside of Qatar), can dine at the theater-style Global Brasserie, flanked by its impressive wine cellar.

items.title: Singapore Airlines KrisFlyer Gold Lounge
items.caption: Singapore Airlines' KrisFlyer Gold Lounge offers weary business travelers a relaxing place to work, with complimentary Wi-Fi throughout and Internet workstations placed in the lounge's outdoor area, overlooking water features and lush greenery.

items.title: British Airways Concorde Room
items.caption: Privacy is key at Heathrow's exclusive Concorde Room, where visitors enjoy meals in private booths and are free to relax in private cabanas with day beds.

items.title: Air France UM Transit Lounge
items.caption: Air France has several luxurious lounges, but one of the most distinct is the UM Transit Lounge at Paris's Charles de Gaulle. The lounge caters to unaccompanied minors, giving them a safe place to play video games, read, and watch movies during long layovers.

items.title: Virgin Atlantic JFK Clubhouse
items.caption: More chic uptown cocktail bar than airport lounge, Virgin Atlantic's JFK Clubhouse also has a Clubhouse Spa with Dr. Hauschka and Bumble & Bumble products.

items.title: Finnair Lounge
items.caption: This bright, spacious lounge stays true to its Scandinavian roots, with Finnish and Nordic-inspired furniture, "Finnair Blue" computer workstations, and even Marimekko table settings.

items.title: Star Alliance Lounge
items.caption: Opening this summer, the revamped Star Alliance lounge at LAX takes its inspiration from Southern California's mid-century modern tradition. The lounge's outdoor space includes a cozy fireplace.

items.title: Qantas First Lounge
items.caption: Sydney's Qantas First Lounge offers a Payot Paris day spa framed by an impressive vertical garden, featuring more than 8,400 plants.

shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Are you fed up with cranky travelers, overpriced airport food, and the endless hunt for a power outlet? Check in to one of these swanky airport lounges, where amenities range from complimentary pajamas (for your slumber in a private nap room) to meals prepared by Michelin-starred chefs.

Check in to one of these swanky airport lounges, where amenities range from complimentary pajamas (for your slumber in a private nap room) to meals prepared by Michelin-starred chefs.

fields.caption: Part of a $1.2 billion expansion at JFK, Delta's 24,000-square-foot flagship Sky Club is also home to the airline's first Sky Deck, an outdoor terrace designed in conjunction with _Architectural Digest_.

shortLinksItems.hed: These Cliff Views Rival The Grand Canyon
shortLinksItems.dek: Daredevils, this one's for you. The views from spots like the White Cliffs of Dover, Half Dome, and the Cliffs of Moher are as beautiful as they are vertigo-inducing.
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: These Cliff Views Rival The Grand Canyon
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: The views from spots like the White Cliffs of Dover, Half Dome, and the Cliffs of Moher are as beautiful as they are vertigo-inducing.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: These Cliff Views Rival The Grand Canyon
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: The views from spots like the White Cliffs of Dover, Half Dome, and the Cliffs of Moher are as beautiful as they are vertigo-inducing.

items.title: [Cliffs of Moher](http://www.cliffsofmoher.ie/)
items.caption:
County Clare, Ireland

----------
Stretching for five miles along Ireland’s western coast, the Cliffs of Moher are a sight more than 300 million years in the making. At their highest, the cliffs soar an impressive 702 feet above the Atlantic Ocean, offering the million visitors who visit each year incredible views sure to leave hearts racing (both from the beauty and the height).

items.title: [White Cliffs of Dover](http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/white-cliffs-dover/)
items.caption:
Kent, United Kingdom

----------
These famous bluffs along England’s southeastern coast are as rich in history as they are in beauty. They stand tall along the Strait of Dover, separating England from France and continental Europe. During World War I, the first bomb to hit the U.K. fell in the town of Dover, and it served as a prominent location during WWII as well. But nowadays, the city is best known for the beauty of its chalky white cliffs.
items.credit: Photo courtesy of Dover District Council

items.title: [Preikestolen](http://www.visitnorway.com/us/product/?pid=31157)
items.caption:
Rogaland, Norway

----------

Preikestolen, or Pulpit Rock, rises high over Lysefjord in Rogaland, Norway. This 1,982-foot-tall cliff offers stunning views, especially for any hikers brave enough to walk right up to its edge. According to legend, if seven sisters marry seven brothers from the surrounding area, Pulpit Rock will break from the mountain and tumble into the fjord below. We recommend planning your trip on a day when no weddings are scheduled at Preikestolen, just to be safe.

items.title: [Grand Canyon](http://www.nps.gov/grca/index.htm)
items.caption:
Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona

----------

No list of incredible cliffs would be complete without the Grand Canyon. The majestic attraction runs along 277 miles of the Colorado River and is up to a mile deep and 18 miles wide. Peering out at the canyon walls offers colorful views of three of the four eras of geological time. For an even more thrilling experience, wander over to the glass-bottomed Grand Canyon Skywalk. The horseshoe-shaped bridge juts out 70 feet from the canyon’s wall and rises 4,000 feet above the Colorado River.
items.credit: © David R. Frazier Photolibrary, Inc. / Alamy

items.title: Cabo Girão
items.caption:
Madeira, Portugal

----------

This steep sea cliff looms over the southern coast of Madeira, an island in the archipelago of the same name. At 1,932 feet above the sea, Cabo Girão is one of Europe’s highest cliffs. A glass-bottomed platform was installed in 2012, allowing visitors to pretend to defy gravity by standing out over the edge and looking down at the water below.

items.title: [Kalaupapa Cliffs](http://www.nps.gov/kala/contacts.htm)
items.caption:
Molokai, Hawaii

----------

The cliffs at Kalaupapa National Historical Park on the Hawaiian island of Molokai are some of the steepest in the world, towering 1,600 feet above sea level. Once a leper colony, Kalaupapa's remote cliffs are now known for their sheer impressiveness and steepness.

items.title: [Mount Thor](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-06-10/mount-thor-canada-maphead-ken-jennings)
items.caption:
Nunavut, Canada

----------

The name Mount Thor may inspire fear or respect—as well it should, considering this is the steepest, tallest cliff in the world. Thor reaches a staggering 4,101 feet above sea level, and the utter greatness of its vertical incline kept it from being successfully ascended until 1965. Today, it remains a challenging and sought-after conquest for rock climbers.

items.title: [Cliffs of Étretat](http://www.etretat.net/office-de-tourisme-etretat/modules/content/content.php?page=falaises&lang=en)
items.caption:
Normandy, France

----------

Located along France's Alabaster Coast, these cliffs offer more than just steep walls. Climb to the top and you'll have views of arched rock formations, as well as scenery that inspired [Claude Monet](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/da/Claude_Monet_The_Cliffs_at_Etretat.jpg). At various points along the cliffs' 80-mile stretch, you can spot natural sculptures that are said to resemble an elephant, among other things.

items.title: [Half Dome](http://www.nps.gov/yose/photosmultimedia/hikinghalfdome.htm)
items.caption:
Yosemite, California

----------

Half Dome, one of Yosemite National Park’s most famous rock formations, is technically not a cliff, but the dizzying views and steep rock faces of this massive formation earn it a place on this list. The peak was once considered inaccessible, but hikers with the proper permits can attempt this challenging ascent today and gaze from the 8,800-foot summit onto the Yosemite Valley below.
items.credit: Kenny Karst / DNC Parks & Resorts at Yosemite, Inc.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

shortLinksItems.dek: Unless you have really adventurous taste buds, it might take a dare before you’re willing to sample any of these delicacies.
shortLinksItems.hed: 10 Unusual Foods We Dare You to Eat

items.title: SNAKE WINE
items.caption: Used in Chinese medicine to treat rheumatism and other ailments, this beverage combines fermented rice wine with such venomous reptiles as vipers. It’s believed the alcohol in the wine dissolves the poison, rendering it safe to drink.

items.title: CHITLINS
items.caption: Also known as chitterlings, small intestines (typically those of pigs) get boiled to tenderness, then served with turnip greens and other Southern sides.

items.title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN OYSTERS
items.caption: Whether you call them prairie oysters or calf fries, there’s no changing the fact that these delicacies are bull’s testicles. They’re often served fried, but competition festivals devoted to the rumored aphrodisiac showcase every preparation, from chocolate-covered to sushi.

items.title: CHAUDIN
items.caption: Similar to haggis, this Cajun specialty begins with a stuffed pig’s stomach. The main difference is the stuffing, which—unlike the Scottish dish—doesn’t typically contain other bits of offal. Rather, it’s just aromatics, vegetables, and bread.

items.title: FRIED TARANTULAS
items.caption: Aracnophobes could either consider this crispy dish—available in Cambodia—sweet, sweet revenge or the worst thing imaginable. They come with or without legs, and you can also request one “in the sack,” which also contains the heart and eggs.

items.title: BALUT
items.caption: A boiled developing duck embryo may not seem like a tasty treat to most people in the Western hemisphere, but it’s commonly consumed in the Philippines and other parts of Asia.

items.title: PENIS
items.caption: We know what you’re thinking: _Ouch. _People around the world gobble up the nether regions of several animals, including ox, deer, goat and donkey. You can find them in simmered in soups and roasted on a kebab, among other preparations

items.title: BEEF BRAINS
items.caption: We hear squishy cerebellum crisps up quite nicely once it’s fried. And if you need extra motivation to get it down the hatch, consider this: The bovine variety is considered a good source of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants.

items.title: TUNA EYES
items.caption: Chefs in Japan frequently fry these giant peepers, which are said to have a jelly-like consistency, with heaps of garlic and soy sauce.

items.title: WITCHETTY GRUBS
items.caption:
According to those who’ve tried them, these fried fatties taste like a combination of nuts, scrambled eggs, and mozzarella.   













**More on unusual foods:**




[The Most Dangerous Foods](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/most-dangerous-foods)




[The Smelliest Food in the World](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/04/weird-food-from-around-the-world)




[Why Airline Food Tastes So Bad](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/04/why-airline-food-tastes-so-bad)

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: 10 Unusual Foods We Dare You to Eat

fields.caption: Used in Chinese medicine to treat rheumatism and other ailments, this beverage combines fermented rice wine with such venomous reptiles as vipers. It’s believed the alcohol in the wine dissolves the poison, rendering it safe to drink.

fields.name: Sarah Bruning
fields.shortBio: A Californian by birth, New Yorker by dwelling and Spaniard at heart, Sarah thrives on finding affordable ways to explore cities across the globe—especially through the medium of food.
fields.bio: A Californian by birth, New Yorker by dwelling and Spaniard at heart, Sarah thrives on finding affordable ways to explore cities across the globe. Living abroad in Madrid during college (University of Southern California) first sparked her wanderlust, and since then, she's hiked through Puerto Rican rainforests, kayaked off the shores of Thailand and inspected historic palaces in India. But no matter where she goes, her favorite experiences almost always involve food, whether it's hitting up a cabbie's favorite spot for kati rolls in Delhi or wandering the narrow stalls of Bangkok's Chatuchak Market to find the best fresh noodles and street snacks.

Living abroad in Madrid during college (University of Southern California) first sparked her wanderlust, and since then, she's hiked through Puerto Rican rainforests, kayaked off the shores of Thailand and inspected historic palaces in India. But no matter where she goes, her favorite experiences almost always involve food, whether it's hitting up a cabbie's favorite spot for kati rolls in Delhi or wandering the narrow stalls of Bangkok's Chatuchak Market to find the best fresh noodles and street snacks.

featureContentItems.hed: 10 Travel Gear Fails: They're So Bad, They're Genius
featureContentItems.dek: When it comes to the gadgets we take with us on the road there are some [obvious hits](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-27/flight-diverted-after-passengers-fight-over-leg-room)—and some pretty epic misses. Here are some of our favorite products that shot for the stars and landed in a whole different galaxy.

items.title: Skyrest Inflatable Travel Pillow
items.caption: Does someone in the window seat want to get up to go to the bathroom? Too bad. No one’s getting past this fortress of comfort. Inflate it when you’re ready for a nap, and trap your seat mates (and yourself) for the remainder of that transatlantic flight.

items.title: Wearable Sleeping Bag
items.caption: You’ll be ready to set up camp anywhere with this sleeping bag. Under a tree? On the street? Done! Built-in arms and legs keep you toasty at night in the middle of the woods, but the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man look leaves something to be desired.

items.title: Wearable Sleeping Bag
items.caption: You’ll be ready to set up camp anywhere with this sleeping bag. Under a tree? On the street? Done! Built-in arms and legs keep you toasty at night, though the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man look leaves something to be desired.

items.title: Micro Kickboard Luggage Scooter
items.caption: Running to your gate is for chumps. Now *scooting* to the gate, that's the ticket. You and the 5-year-olds will breeze past airport crowds together.

items.title: Supersmoker
items.caption: Why put out your cigarette to answer a call when you can answer a call *with* your smoke? Supersmoker is an electronic cigarette with a built-in Bluetooth speaker and speakerphone—so yes, your cigarette also plays music. The future is now.

items.title: The Pee Pocket
items.caption: Finally, a device that gives women the equality they've long been seeking—they, too, can pee anywhere. Of course, afterwards you’ll end up with a bag of urine, but that’s just a minor detail, right?

items.title: Skyrest Inflatable Travel Pillow
items.caption: Is that lady in the window seat trying to get up to go to the bathroom? Too bad: No one’s getting past this fortress of comfort. Inflate it when you’re ready for a nap, and trap your seatmates (and yourself) for the remainder of that transatlantic flight.

items.title: Flyebaby Infant Plane Seat
items.caption: This device gives Junior his own hammock using the chair in front of you on the plane, because *that* seems like a smart idea. Until, you know, the guy in front of you leans back, or the drink service comes around, or someone needs to get out of their chair...

items.title: TV Hat
items.caption: Never leave the TV at home again. This hat holds your phone at the end of its exceptionally large brim and has two pull-down shades that block out the world around you. Pretend you’re at the movies and simultaneously stay protected from the sun. It's a natural combination.

items.title: Musical Sleep Mask
items.caption: Why waste valuable carry-on space with a sleep mask and a pair of headphones when you can get both in the *same package*? It's like Bose for your eyes.

items.title: Shunwei Fry Holder
items.caption: Coffee and water are out. Upgrade your car's basic cup holders into universal French fry holders. The gadget is capable of holding any “standard” fry carton and helps keep your favorite side dish upright during a road trip. Or a morning commute.

items.title: Ostrich Pillow
items.caption: Place your hands and head inside to create a private nap zone no matter where you are. (Or just make everyone around you nervous about your mental state.) Bonus: Since your whole face is inside, no one will even be able to tell it’s you.

featureContentItems.seoTitle: 10 Travel Gear Fails: They're So Bad, They're Genius
featureContentItems.seoDescription: When it comes to the gadgets we take with us on the road there are some obvious hits—and some pretty epic misses.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: 10 Travel Gear Fails: They're So Bad, They're Genius
featureContentItems.socialDescription: When it comes to the gadgets we take with us on the road there are some obvious hits—and some pretty epic misses.

fields.name: Emily Price
fields.shortBio: Emily is a writer and craft beer enthusiast based in San Francisco.
fields.bio: Emily is a journalist based in San Francisco, California. Her work has also appeared in *Popular Mechanics*, *PC World*, Entrepreneur, *Cosmopolitan*, and Mashable.

featureContentItems.hed: 5 Easy Escapes from the World’s Top Business Centers
featureContentItems.dek: Next time your better half has meetings halfway around the world, surprise him or her with a side trip to one of these off-the-beaten-path (and definitely romantic) destinations.
featureContentItems.body:
__FROM:__ London

__TO:__ New Forest National Park

__TRIP TIME:__ 1.5-hr. drive

__THE HOTEL WE LOVE:__ [Lime Wood](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-kingdom/lyndhurst/lime-wood) 

Set on 20 acres of forest and moor, this Georgian manor house has freestanding soaking tubs in its Main House guest rooms, one of the best spas in England, and an upscale yet utterly unpretentious restaurant by award- winning chef Angela Hartnett. In other words, bring on the pampering.

[#image: /photos/53daf6c6dcd5888e145d93c8]||||||



__FROM:__ São Paulo

__TO:__ Catuçaba

__TRIP TIME__: 3-hr. drive

__THE HOTEL WE LOVE:__ [Fazenda Catuçaba](http://www.catucaba.com/pt/index.mhtml) 

This colonial eco-farm 30 minutes from the historic town of São Luiz do Paraitinga is truly away from it all: There’s no TV, cell phone service, or Internet. But there’s still plenty to do—like horseback riding, canoeing, and hiking.

-------------------------


__FROM:__ Shanghai

__TO:__ Hangzhou

__TRIP TIME__: 2-hr. train ride

__THE HOTEL WE LOVE:__ [Amanfayun](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/china/liuxia/amanfayun) 

Each suite was once a family’s home, and the plan of the hotel follows the original village footpath. Hike uphill to visit the ancient Buddhist temples; have massages in the excellent spa (which incorporates traditional Chinese medicine); and, of course, sip tea in the rustic teahouse. You’ll swear you’ve somehow taken a train to the nineteenth-century Chinese countryside.


[#image: /photos/53dac9e6dcd5888e145cd32d]||||||


__FROM:__ Singapore

__TO:__ Langkawi

__TRIP TIME:__ 1.5-hr. flight

__THE HOTEL WE LOVE:__ [The Datai](http://www.thedatai.com/langkawi/) 

The terraces and private pools are very secluded . . . and very sexy. The one-bedroom villas (with their comfy white beds) are the ones to book.

----------------


__FROM:__ Tokyo

__TO:__ Fujiya

__TRIP TIME:__ 3-hr. train ride

__THE HOTEL WE LOVE:__ [Ginzan Onsen Fujiya](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/yamagata/ginza-hot-spring-fujiya-inn) 

The inn was designed by famed Japanese architect Kengo Kuma, with five different furo, or hot tubs. One is in a room with louvered shutters, so you can sit in steaming-hot water as the snow blows in; the other is at the bottom of a deep, well-like stone-lined space. Tubs are big enough for two.

[#image: /photos/54885ae7860c74c1162c7c8b]||||||

*For more romantic travel ideas, check out our [Romantic Getaway Guide](https://cnt.conde.io/reports/special-report-romantic-getaway-guide).*

featureContentItems.hed: The One Dish to Eat in Venice
featureContentItems.dek: Don’t leave Venice without trying this classic dish. Plus: how to eat it, how to order, how to pay, and some useful dos and don’ts.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: The One Dish to Eat in Venice
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Don’t leave Venice without trying this classic dish. Plus: how to eat it, how to order, how to pay, and some useful dos and don’ts.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: The One Dish to Eat in Venice
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Don’t leave Venice without trying this classic dish. Plus: how to eat it, how to order, how to pay, and some useful dos and don’ts.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53db238cdcd5888e145e7b35]|||"A beautiful and intriguing place" where "every view is like a painting," [Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/venice) won over our readers with its "unbelievable atmosphere." There's "not a bad meal to be had in this city," and it's a "paradise for [shopping](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/venice-italy-shopping-secrets) and [fashion](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/08/venice-italy-designer-fashion-guide)." "Somehow for me this city is apart from this world. You can write pages describing it but it would never be enough. It's the perfect experience to wake up in the morning and have a espresso on a narrow street and to end it in a gondola in the evening"|||

**You can't leave Venice without eating…**



 _Sardèle in saòr._ A small dish of fried sardines marinated in white onions, vinegar, raisins, and pine nuts, _sardèle in saòr_ is type of _cicheti_ (“_ki-ke-tee_”), the city’s take on a pre-dinner light bite accompanied by a glass of wine or a spritzer cocktail. Head to one of the many _bacari_ (small bars) along Venice’s canals and mix with locals for this early evening tradition.



**How to eat it:** At most bacari you’ll be able to choose from a number of cicheti. The bartender will give you a small plate, which alongside the _sardèle in saòr_ may include _baccalà mantecato_ (dried salted cod slowly cooked in milk and served on a piece of toasted bread or a wedge of polenta) or _polpette_ (small, fried meatballs). In some of the smaller _bacari_, most people will stand at the bar as they tuck into their cicheti, but there are almost always at least a couple of small tables for those who prefer to eat sitting.





[#image: /photos/53e2f304dddaa35c30f6620e]|||_Cicheti_ and white wine|||

**How to order:** If your Italian is up to scratch or you’re feeling brave, try asking directly: “_Uno di questi e un bicchiere di prosecco/vino bianco_” (“one of these, please, and a glass of prosecco/white wine”). You can point, especially if there is a wide selection and you’re not sure exactly what’s what.







**Do you tip?** You pay for what you eat, after eating. If you stumble upon one of the bacari during _aperitivo_ time (pre-dinner drinks around 7-8pm), ordering a drink might also entitle you to pick freely from a finger food buffet. (The drink is usually more expensive than usual, between € 8 and €10.) Tips are not mandatory but appreciated if the service or food—or both—are exceptional.







**Local tip:** Cicheti are available from lunch onwards, but the best time to go is pre-dinner (aperitivo time). Watch out for the extra charge when sitting at a table, rather than being served over the bar counter. Children are welcome: You can have your aperitivo with kids around; Italians do. Children can have their own drink (a fruit juice, or water mixed with syrup such as mint or barley _orzata_).







**Etiquette tip:** Do: Eat cicheti as they are served (no additional dressings or sauces of sorts). Don’t: Order a cappuccino with your cicheti; they should be eaten with wine, cocktails, or a beer, although non-alcoholic options are also fine.















**More travel etiquette:**







[The One Dish You Should Never Order in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/the-best-food-in-rome)







[Don’t Leave Florence Without Eating This One Dish](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/the-best-dish-in-florence-italy)







[The One Dish to Eat in Naples, Italy](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/06/food-etiquette-guide-eating-in-naples)



_Emily Knight is a manager with [Context Travel Walking Tours,](http://www.contexttravel.com) a company chosen as one of [Condé Nast Traveler's top travel specialists](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists)._

fields.caption: "A beautiful and intriguing place" where "every view is like a painting," [Venice](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/venice) won over our readers with its "unbelievable atmosphere." There's "not a bad meal to be had in this city," and it's a "paradise for [shopping](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/venice-italy-shopping-secrets) and [fashion](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/08/venice-italy-designer-fashion-guide)." "Somehow for me this city is apart from this world. You can write pages describing it but it would never be enough. It's the perfect experience to wake up in the morning and have a espresso on a narrow street and to end it in a gondola in the evening."
fields.title:
24.

Venice
